page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 62: Line 62:
===29 January===
===29 January===
â
[[File:Demonstrators on Army Truck in Tahrir Square, Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|Demonstrators standing on an army vehicle in [[Tahrir Square]], Cairo. The sign reads: "Leave, you tyrant. Down with Mubarak."]]
+
[[File:Demonstrators on Army Truck in Tahrir Square, Cairo.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators standing on an army vehicle in [[Tahrir Square]], Cairo. The sign reads: "Leave, you tyrant. Down with Mubarak."]]
  +
[[File:Protesters marching in Cairo - 29JAN2011.jpg|thumb|Protesters in Cairo]]
The night of 28/29 January was quieter in Cairo with fewer reports of looting than in previous days.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-301-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 30/1 â Egypt Protests|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
The night of 28/29 January was quieter in Cairo with fewer reports of looting than in previous days.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-301-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 30/1 â Egypt Protests|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
Line 69: Line 69:
Protesters were described by reporters as more confident and even celebratory as they felt they were nearing their objectiveâthe end of Mubarak's presidencyâalthough they had no tangible evidence of this.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm" /> An eyewitness told Al Jazeera that people of all ages and both genders were present. Demonstrators violated the curfew and no one attempted to stop them. Looting was also reported, while no police were visible.<ref>[http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/egypt-protests-hosni-mubarak/2011/01/29/id/384360 "Egyptian Protesters Defy Curfew Again"]. 29 January 2011. ''[[Newsmax]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref>
Protesters were described by reporters as more confident and even celebratory as they felt they were nearing their objectiveâthe end of Mubarak's presidencyâalthough they had no tangible evidence of this.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm" /> An eyewitness told Al Jazeera that people of all ages and both genders were present. Demonstrators violated the curfew and no one attempted to stop them. Looting was also reported, while no police were visible.<ref>[http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/egypt-protests-hosni-mubarak/2011/01/29/id/384360 "Egyptian Protesters Defy Curfew Again"]. 29 January 2011. ''[[Newsmax]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref>
â   â
[[File:Protesters marching in Cairo - 29JAN2011.jpg|thumb|Protesters in Cairo]]
 
In [[Beni Suef]], south of Cairo, 17 protesters were killed by police as the protesters attempted to attack two police stations. In Abu Zabaal prison in Cairo, eight people were killed as police clashed with inmates trying to escape. According to a ''[[Reuters]]'' tally, these unconfirmed deaths brought the death toll to at least 100.<ref name="reuters3">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70S0LX20110129|title=Update 1-Death Toll in Egypt's Protests Tops 100 â Sources |work=[[Reuters]]|}}</ref> Several [[Islamist]] [[terrorists]] and others escaped.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bradley, John R.|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-1352090/EGYPT-RIOTS-Hosni-Mubarak-beware-comes-next.html#ixzz1ChE3Srqm|title=Egypt Riots: Hosni Mubarak Must Go, But Beware What Comes Next |work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Prison overcrowding and [[police brutality]] were voiced by many of the protesters.<ref name="reuters3" /> Emad Gad, an analyst with the [[Al-Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies]], said that he had obtained information from a trustworthy source that "there have been orders from the very top to free known [[Felony|felons]] from the prisons, to arm them and to let them mingle with protesters."<ref name="Spiegel Anarchy">{{Cite news|last1=Steinvorth|first1=Daniel|last2=Windfuhr|first=Volkhard|work=[[Der Spiegel]] |title=Mubarak will Ãgypten brennen sehen|trans_title=Mubarak Wants To See Egypt Burn|language=[[German language|German]]|date=30 January 2011|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,742498,00.html|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Two Egyptian policemen jailed following the death of anti-corruption activist Khaled Said were among the hundreds of prisoners that escaped in Cairo that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html|title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300}}</ref>
In [[Beni Suef]], south of Cairo, 17 protesters were killed by police as the protesters attempted to attack two police stations. In Abu Zabaal prison in Cairo, eight people were killed as police clashed with inmates trying to escape. According to a ''[[Reuters]]'' tally, these unconfirmed deaths brought the death toll to at least 100.<ref name="reuters3">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70S0LX20110129|title=Update 1-Death Toll in Egypt's Protests Tops 100 â Sources |work=[[Reuters]]|}}</ref> Several [[Islamist]] [[terrorists]] and others escaped.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bradley, John R.|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-1352090/EGYPT-RIOTS-Hosni-Mubarak-beware-comes-next.html#ixzz1ChE3Srqm|title=Egypt Riots: Hosni Mubarak Must Go, But Beware What Comes Next |work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Prison overcrowding and [[police brutality]] were voiced by many of the protesters.<ref name="reuters3" /> Emad Gad, an analyst with the [[Al-Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies]], said that he had obtained information from a trustworthy source that "there have been orders from the very top to free known [[Felony|felons]] from the prisons, to arm them and to let them mingle with protesters."<ref name="Spiegel Anarchy">{{Cite news|last1=Steinvorth|first1=Daniel|last2=Windfuhr|first=Volkhard|work=[[Der Spiegel]] |title=Mubarak will Ãgypten brennen sehen|trans_title=Mubarak Wants To See Egypt Burn|language=[[German language|German]]|date=30 January 2011|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,742498,00.html|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Two Egyptian policemen jailed following the death of anti-corruption activist Khaled Said were among the hundreds of prisoners that escaped in Cairo that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html|title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300}}</ref>
